Xsyon Xsyon Xsyon...

What can I say to persuade you to play this game. Lets be up front... Xsyon isnt for everyone. This isn't a mainstream game. It's a niche game. A free world, open ended sandbox. Not sandbox themed. You get what you put into the game. There is alot of ambiguity, and alot of hiden mechanics that even the veteran players don't know. The learning curve is steep. If you have ever played any large space-based mmo's before their tutorial systems, you know what a daunting learning curve that is. This is no short-termed end-game. Here is what my personal opinion of the game is:

Pros:
Open ended, there is no end.
In depth crafting system.
Sandbox, full customization of tribal areas.
Very helpful player base, not alot of drama.
PvE or PvP Server option.
A VERY willing Developer who listens extremely close to their player base.
Big ambitions for future expansions.

Cons:
Currently a low player population
Steep learning curve
Hard to solo in the game
Slower development

While there are alot of reviews on the billing of the game, I am not fixated on subscriptions. It costs money to make a video game. Time = money. But to be a part of the metamorphasis of this game has beeen awesome. I have enjoyed this game solo and as a large tribe (guild). It is tough going solo unless you are near a larger tribe or willing to travel. That is what I ENJOYED as one of the challenges. The transparancy of development is a refreshing change and I truly feel the maturity level of the existing players is a welcome change. For those that are looking for the next best thing"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game years ago when it first came out and all you could do was terraform the landscape. It quickly lost my attention. I picked it up when it came out on Steam and outside of the low server population, this is a must have game for those into survival/building games. If you like crafting, gathering supplies, exploring, and building structures you will find plenty to do. You can build roads, terraform the landscape, farm the land, cut down trees, build everything in game, and all of this is visible to other players. Everything in game ages and/or gains xp. That Reverant that killed you an hour ago, stole your clothes and shovel from your corpse and now struts around with those items on him, taunting you to come kill him to get it back.

Amazingly this game is ran by a single developer; yet, has more thought and work done to it then most MMO's on the market today. If you are looking for a game where twitchy fingers wins the day, this is not that game. This is a survival game, with what could be an attempt at a Trading simulation game. Although there are many aspects of the game that remain unpolished, it is extremely playable and stable, and simple in many regards.

The learning curve is somewhere in between WoW and EVE online. It does not appear to have the same depth as EVE Online, but give this game a full staff of developers and it could easily come close over time. The next UO, probably. The next WoW, possibly. It just would depend which direction it went. Of course, neither matter if the graphics do not keep up.

The immediate downfall of the game is that the communications systems in game are horrible and most people are into solo gameplay. A new person joining the game is dropped into the middle of a huge map (literally can take hours to travel from one part to another). The server population is so low that I have only seen other players when I requested to meet them in person and travelled to their location. However, everyone is extremely nice and friendly. If the developer moved in the direction of an EVE economy I think this game would have serious staying power, and be able to expand rapidly. However, if one cannot view at distances items for sale, then one might as well be playing a solo or cooperative game, not an MMO. This game needs some way to allow a greater sense of where you as an individual, as a tribe stand in relation to others.

Overall, I recommend this game, with the reservations noted above.

Early Access Review

For fans of sandbox MMOs Xsyon is a must.  This game has A LOT of character and offers a very unique experience than your dime a dozen mainstream MMO.  I played it for a while before it came to steam and for a fan of Ultima Online and SWG there are a lot of familiar mecanics here, namely a skill gain by use system.  Everything you do from walking, swimming, crafting, lumberjacking to foraging has a skill attached to it and the more you do that particular thing, the better you get at it.  So everything you do has meaning.  Like real life Xsyon seeks to create a virtual realm where you can basically learn and improve on whatever you wish.  There is also building and terraforming.  You can claim a plot of land, shape it and start building on it - completely open world, where everyone can see it happening.  Guilds can build veritable towns.  You also have the option to choose either a PVP or PVE server, so those who hate ganking will find a very enjoyable and casual gameplay experience on the PVE server along with a very friendly community.

One word of warning though.  If combat is your main thing then you might want to give this game a little more time to develop.  The hunting is also a work in progress since there are no ranged weapons/bows as of yet.  Chasing a squirrel through the woods when it's at a fraction of health just to have it jump in a lake and run off because your stamina got too low to persue it is not my idea of fun.  But if you like building, crafting and resource gathering like I do, you will love this MMO.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, the community in this game is awesome, amazing. By and large it is the most mature, friendly and helpful in-game community I have experienced. There aren't very many people playing but there are enough active tribes that would love to recruit you and you won't have to be isolated unless that is how you want to play it.

Pros: The community. The unique and quirky style, which is a post-apocalyptic- zombie- low fantasy - Native American inspired -with brightly colored mutant animals that want to eat you - combo. It is a bloody mental mix but I really, really like it. There is immense variety in crafting. The world is beautiful and pretty huge. You can farm and build mind boggling structures. Fully player-driven world. Development is ongoing with new features coming in occasionally and fixes regularly.

Cons: low population. Crafting is somewhat grindy and a clickfest. There isn't really an end-game, you really have to take responsibility to create you own experience because the game is player-driven to the extent where you need to self-motivate 100%.  PVP isn't really a thing, I mean there is the PVP server, but no one actually PVPs because 1) combat system is not very good, 2) there aren't enough players on the PVP server to feel justified in killing those few brave souls who care to show up because then you'd be all alone, and 3) there isn't much reason to PVP... most people play this game to roleplay building their town/ mansion and explore the world. This last one isn't really a con IMO.

Over all, quite a few cons - but those pros carry much more weight for me. The unique style and feel of the world along with the chance to be really creative and build up amazing looking communities with some really great people - that is basically what I want from a game and so rarely experience.

Not everyone will appreciate Xsyon so research thoroughly before you buy. If you are like me you'll be stuck. I have played for over three years (most of that time I didn't launch through steam so my hours played are misleading) and though I am too busy these days to find much time for games, I keep coming back.

so my thoughts on xsyon - I'd rank it a solid 7 outta 10 in its current state - it is playable and enjoyable - the graphics are solid for a early access indie game - for a sandbox game the grinding is not bad - compared to similar titles its down right pleasent - the game revolves on a end of the world scenario where people try to survive alone or in tribes while rebuilding - terraforming and building structures finding scrap metals plastics and other goods in rubbish piles or cutting down trees and getting rocks - fishing hunting or farming for food - all in all a pretty standard sandbox

so why should you buy it? The community while small (semi average for a sandbox indie) it is a polite and dedicated group - the 15dollars a month keeps most angry children and trolls from really being a threat to your gaming exp and to me thats worth it after having been trolled in dozens of games (didn't work but still is a waste of my limited time) with them randomly attacking me or blowing something up for no reason and taking hours and hours to repair (far more hours then it would take for me to earn the 15 dollars) so as such the monthly fee keeping the game going me not having to buy 25-40$ a month/week in cash shops to keep up with people and no paid expansion packs or DLC means I am exactly the same as everyone else in the game complete and total fairness - yeah skill based put into the game and be stronger not paid to win - the xsyon style I do enjoy the tribal indian post apocalypse blend, the several choices of buildings tools weapons and armor was very nice as I'm able to really create either a scavenger society of metal and tires or a pioneer camp of logs or even a grass and twig town allowing for large customization of my settlement

so now time for the pro and cons
- great sandbox building set with structures being as big or as small as you need with several varities of buildings fences and
- lots of choices for clothing weapons and tool styles each needing different resources
- limited grinding for resources or construction - moderate to average on skills high level skills actually making you work for them instead of being given to you.
- good blends of skill selection - starting kits tailored to your choices at start up - select axe as your weapon you get a axe select pick you get a pick ect ect - no starting short sword and shield generic kit
- solid community willing to talk and help

cons
-the games a bit confusing out of the gate - and needs a new tutorial / upgraded wiki majorly but after a week its not bad
- limited decorations for inside a house - outside a house plenty of choices but not allot of furniture rugs ect
- no current taming system - its in the works and I will remove this once its in
- combat is a bit hit and miss atm - you can kill most small animals (squirels hampsters bunnys) but they tend to run from you and the actual click to hit system is a bit sensative meaning you have to hit a small animal running through the grass

- no ranged combat - only melee weapons sorry

the pro/con - this is the section that could go either way for you - some like these options some don't - and some I just have mixed feelings toward

-few to no trolls - might not be a big deal to you but I have a job / family / and life away from computer so knowing I won't have to log in and deal with some angry child blowing up half my town cause his parents told him he couldn't go out with friends is major bonus for me

- low player base - this is a game of hundreds to thousands not hundreds of thousands it is ment to be a small market game catering to the people who enjoy this kind of game not to the masses - to me this is big as finding a unique game mmo not just a mini run your own server game is a big pro for me as I feel like I know those around me at same time people get a bit quiet at times which can be a turn off for others

so would I buy this game again? Yes - Will I play this game hard core for years? probably off and on yes like any sandbox this is a game you will keep coming back to once you have had your fill and keep enjoying it

Xsyon is a open world post apocalypse sandbox set after some unknown event that wipes all traces of technology off the face of the earth.

The game is set around Lake Tahoe and use the USGS Geological survey data of the surrounding area between California and Nevada. You have the ability to terraform the terrain to help you build a small shack or a large city. You can’t dig tunnels or go underground.

Xsyon Features a fairly good skill system that allows you to craft weapons, tools, armor, clothing, buildings and baskets. You can fish anywhere there is water and cook at a campfire, there is also a recipe system that allows you create food which has buffs.

You're able to place totem poles which allow you to control land, protect your containers and prevent players from damaging you(pvp server). This also gives you a place to re spawn.

I was a big Star Wars Galaxies player back in the day and this game checks a lot of the SWG boxes, yes i'm aware of the emulator.

For city builder/planners this game is a lot of fun, there are some bugs its honestly a very relaxing game to play (on the pve server).

The playable area is only about 20-30% of the actual game world map itself. If the population ever grew the game world is ready to expand to about 3-4x the current size once the game leaves prelude(i think ea and prelude are the same thing now).

PvP is fun if your able to join an existing tribe, I'm mainly a crafter but i do like PvP, i have a character on both servers. Make sure you get into an existing tribe on the War server if you join that server. (dont cry if you get jumped and lose all your stuff thats the point of the war server).

It gets a lot crap because it was created by 1 person, with only some contractors here and there helping out. But with any bugs or flaws its better than most of the junk that is coming out today.

People complain about the grind because honestly your NOT supposed to grind your skills to level 100 on day 1. If you join a community of players on the server and help out with building a small city you level your skills the intended way. (sorry generation tumblr)

I level upped about half of my basketry skills on my character just making the grass components for our tribes architect. Who in turn was building our starting house.

Xsyon is a better RPG than Fallout4 & The Division :D

Xsyon is a MMO, much like EQ, RS, Wurm and WoW; WoW took 4-5 years to create and had the disposal of the Blizzard staff. Great game
If you love these kinds of games (as I do), you really should consider looking into this one. I share my more detailed thoughts on Xsyon in the following video for those interested ;)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=407VnQyZUAQ

Some Special Things
If you play these kinds of games, you will understand many of the things they have in common, from Crafting gear, to building up your home/settlement/tribe. But here are some things I really enjoy about Xsyon you won't see in most (if any) others like it (so not an exhaustive list - just stuff I really like)...

+ Quest Creation - Make a quest... what are you looking for and what are you rewarding someone with for completing it? Add these details to your quest, and anyone can complete it!

+ Terrain Reforming - When a settlement is abandoned, the structures left behind can be torn down easily. More importantly, when the supported structures are gone, the terrain (any terraforming done) returns pretty quickly to its natural state! How awesome is that?!

+ Skill Up by Doing But Also... - Not only do the skills you use increase as you use them, but at the same time you are doing things (crafting, etc) you are filling an XP bar. When full, you get points to spend on ANY other skills as well. It's a nice combo giving you some options without it being a straight free-for-all.

+ Setting - This takes place in post-apocalyptic Lake Tahoe. The world" is the mountainous area surrounding the lake. Things get more dangerous (and rewarding) the farther you explore away from the lake. Native American influences are heavy here and the combination of that with the apoc setting give this really cool "return to the old world" feel that is really compelling for me."

I bought this game over a month ago and have not regretted making the purchase.  Please note that although my playtime record on steam is low (0.7 hours at the time of writing), it does not give a true reflection as I prefer to use the main Xsyon client - as do many other players.

There are a couple of issues that I have noticed that have crept up on the forums.

1) Subscription. Yes this game is a subscription based model. I know a lot feel its silly to charge a sub for this game. But actually having written in the official forums about possibilities of being free to play, the developer has actually tried testing out different pay models (including changing the sub fee). It was found that free to play created a destructive element in the game, in that it brought players who were not good for the game. Some of the players resorted to exploits, botted and even caused a lot of tension/drama in global chat by being rude/abusive (hence the reason why the majority talk in tribe chat and not global).

The Cash shop idea. Wouldn't be good, Basically you are asking the developer to concentrate on making things for the cash shop rather than developing things for the game or patching bugs etc.

2) It's Alpha. Well the developer has already commented on this. Basically it's on PRELUDE. So no, it not Alpha or Beta but the next step beyond that. I'm not paying to test a game. I am paying to play a game that is playable and published. Fact is that a majority of MMO's are never truly finished" on release
date:
hence why there are patches and expansions.

3) Player numbers and community. Steam stats do not reflect true numbers. Majority of players still use the Xsyon client via the website as it was the default thing to do pre - steam. It's also a fact that a majority only speak in tribe chat. In the past a lot of drama was caused in global chat which became really problematic and had to be sorted out by GMs in game.
The community overall is very mature and helpful. There are many vets who are happy to answer questions. Do understand though that timezone may affect peak hours for this game. I believe the majority of players are in the US/Canada timezones.

Now onto the game

The game tries to be as realistic as possible i.e. meaning you wont be able to kill bears until you have honed and got your skills really high. I believe people have high expectations from the get go and get disappointed because they cannot do the things they want to from the off. Sorry folks but this game is slower paced and longer longevity type gameplaying. Meaning be prepared to put in some hard work before expecting to be able to tackle some of the high end stuff.

1) Crafting and resource gathering. Lot's to craft with many more crafting skills planned for the future.  You will need to either trade or gather resources to be able to craft. Be prepared to spend a lot of time gathering resources so you can grind your craft. Crafting and gathering also have a bonus in that each craft skill has a primary and secondary attributes. I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a game where you need to put in the effort to get the rewards.

Unlike many of the other sandbox survival type games, Xsyon  feels more realistic. for instance...

To survive, you need to either learn to farm and cook your own foods, or fish and hunt to stay alive. Eating and drinking water are critical to this like in real life. You can also forage for berries and other food plants.

Of course things like tools, armor, and weapons wear out, so you can either start trading with other players or learn to make those yourself. The more effort you put into it the better those items will become.

I have been playing this for 3+ years and have made tons of friends in game and had steady entertainment all along. Each new improvement the Developer puts in has only made the game better for me.

If you are looking for a game with long term play that you can grow in, making your lasting mark on the game world, then this game will be right up your alley. In depth crafting system. The materials you choose determine the results and I like how you can choose the armor you wear mostly based on looks since each armor set can be crafted to have the bonuses that you want for your character.


Carts are cool and something I haven’t seen in other games. It’s fun to haul your stash around!



This is a good one to play in a group with friends, especially if you’re planning on some serious town building.

Early Access Review

I've been playing the game for over two years, Xsyon has a lot to offer that others games lack or haven't fleshed out the same systems.

The game takes a little getting used to when you first start playing but quickly you'll learn and figure it out. I remember when I first started there was no tutorial and what wiki that players had started was severely lacking for information but the community was very helpful and didn't shoot you down when you did have questions. Today the game has a in-depth wiki and tutorial when you log in to the game. This is very helpful to new players entering the game needing guidance.

The game in its current state has a lot to offer with in-depth crafting systems, hunting, farming, and cooking. I'm looking forward to seeing the current round of development proceeding forward and trying it out once it makes it in game (pets, mounts, etc etc) you can find current round development under the game section on the main site to see what is next in line.

In game I spend a lot of time on weapon, tool, architecture, and bone crafting. These are the things I enjoy doing most and have put my effort in to be the best at. I really like going out from tribe and hunting, I take pleasure in it and also I need the mats for bonecrafting anyway but I get to explore the server and all the while I get the supplies I need while doing so.

I love the sense of adventure the game offers, I'm really looking forward to some mapping skill eventually, as exploring what is out there and seeing what players have built, gives me joy, as it's really amazing some of the things that come out of the player base. It's also neat running around seeing things change over time, whether it be a new tribe, or watching the terrain revert back to how it once was since, we have terrain reversion now.

Scavenging is by far the one thing I enjoy most out of the game because you never know what recipes or items you will find and I like mapping out scavenging piles. When I say mapping them out, I'm talking about marking which give recipes more so than another or blades, nails, rivets, and the like. I've spent countless hours just running around the map scavenging junk piles looking for the best materials or recipes I could find. It's sort of like playing the lotto.

The farming system is pretty in-depth and I'm looking forward to seeing more and more crop types as development goes on along with more cooking recipes. Cooking alone is by far the best system I have seen in a sandbox MMO, having primary ingredients along with seasonings to boost the buffs you get from the meal your eating is awesome to say the least.

Terraforming in Xsyon is unlike any other and very precise if you need to be with it. Changing the landscape is one thing I look for in a sandbox so that I can shape the land to the way I want it to be, if I was so inclined to do so I could have a terrace system on a mountain top with ramps leading to each section. You can really do a lot with it and the architecture that is in the game really fits the look and feel of Xsyon. There are a lot of design options to choose from along with designs you can do with laying everything out. You're not limited by skill alone to make a certain sized house, if you want a massive structure 8 stories high and have the materials and time to do so, then go for it. There are no limits other than the ones you set for yourself.

The combat system is one reason I like hunting so much, the variables, and directional user input combat like mount and blade is what draws me to it. I have full control over how combat plays out, yes there are random variables that take place but I can race in and do a charged blow and speed away or circle around a opponent. I'm not sitting in one spot watching text scroll and hitting at a determined speed based on skill, stats, and weapon. I determine the combat based on my interaction and yes stats and all that do come in to play but I could lose a battle with a player or creature by miss steps on how I do the combat on my end.

I would recommend this game to anyone, Xsyon is exactly what I want out of a open world sandbox ♥♥♥♥♥♥me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, this is a game still in development, early access so it says, and done by one man. That, in itself, is pretty impressive. The graphics are pretty good for a true sandbox with full terraforming and piecemeal building construction system as well as trees that are actually removed when chopped. All these are rendered obviously which requires a balance between graphics and game performance. It does a good job on that.

The building aspect of the game is very versatile and completely customizable. I have seen rustic cabins, tent villages, stilt village areas over water, tree houses and full on castle like structures as well as mad max looking scrap metal compounds. It allows a great flexibility in customizing your tribe to your liking.

Nice scavenging system where it almost feels like a lotto each scavenge trying to find those rare blueprints folks pay good money for to get the rare architect plans. Robust and fairly complex cooking and farming system recently introduced. Good asset protection with gate permissions, storage bin permissions and cart permissions. We recently saw the first unique use specification for buildings, a commissary, that greatly reduces food decay rates when stored in it. This hints at a lot of great options forthcoming.

The game has some very addictive qualities in certain areas if that is the type of thing you like. The PvE server, the one mostly populated, has a very welcoming and positive community. Helpful to new players and really isn't a lot of griefing or such on their. The PvP server is left alone in that regard allowing your weapons to deal with griefing although I will say that there is not much of a PvP community currently. This Steam release hopefully will breath life back into that.

Is it perfect? No. It functions well, the things it has are decently done, the developer is constantly working to correct bugs and issues brought forth by players and has a lot of very interesting things listed to be upcoming.

With a completely player driven in game economy, no cash shop or credits or other 'currency' to buy and use in game, it really is a player driven economy. No NPCs besides animals and revenants, which are essentially zombies of abandoned tribes that, if they kill you, will take your equipped weapons and armor to fill gaps in what they are currently wearing or wielding. You could come back and be killed by your own weapons. The combat isn't my thing, but a lot of the players have told me the key is to learn the system.

Cooking actually can end up consuming 12 ingredients to make the top end recipes and can buff various attributes, add to healing rates and other things. Pretty complex in that area. Also, you can starve to death of die of thirst, so planning ahead for such is important. Of course, you can drink from any river or the lake. Foraging for food can be done but provides minimal sustenance and making kabobs is a much better way to go.

All and all, a fun and creative game with what could well be a very bright future. I would gladly, and have, recommend this game to folks that are into sandbox games and enjoy building or, like me, hoarding. You can end up with a lot of stuff. Also, when tribes become abandoned and the totems decay away, their goods are open for looting.

With a focus on tribe (community) building and a fully player modified landscape and only player driven economy (with no cash shop) it is a refreshing game that can suck you in for hours on end without you noticing.

Skills are 'grindy' so to speak, leveled up by utilizing those skills. There is no level system. There are experience points that are earned and can be used to level up skills and are often used to level up the more grind intensive skills or just the ones you may not enjoy doing as much.

Currently, I would say the game shows it is in early release and thus I would give it a 75-80 out of 100. Hopefully the changes the developer intends to make can up that a bit.
